intro: Gaura parviflora var. typica, commonly known as the common gaura, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of delicate, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist to wet soils and thrives in full sun, making it a popular choice for wetland gardens. Its foliage is narrow and grass-like, with the flowers appearing in late spring to early summer. The plant is noted for its ability to attract pollinators such as butterflies and bees.
